title: Obama’s Ebola challenge
content:
Obama won ’ t stay locked in the White House until the Ebola crisis dies down , aides said . Obama 's Ebola challenge
The White House playbook for handling natural disasters is clear cut : Get the president in front of the cameras early , pledge every federal resource for the recovery , make a sympathetic visit to the devastated area and never pass up an opportunity to show who ’ s in charge .
But the strategy for dealing with a deadly infectious disease that ’ s unlikely to turn into an epidemic yet is still terrifying to the public ? Murky , at best .
President Barack Obama ’ s deft handling of Hurricane Sandy almost two years ago helped to seal his reelection bid , but the tricky nature of the Ebola fight has renewed questions about Obama ’ s leadership style and his administration ’ s competence — a recurring theme in the midterm elections . The crisis is escalating just as people begin early voting in key states and the campaign for control of the Senate enters the final weeks , returning attention to an unpopular president right when Democrats least want that .
So Obama has been forced to claim ownership of the problem , balancing the tension between his own reluctance to play into the frenzy and the growing public demands that he take dramatic action to protect Americans from further exposure .
He took the unusual step of suspending his travel schedule for the past two days to stay at the White House , where he has consulted with congressional leaders , called foreign leaders and held lengthy meetings with his top advisers . He also authorized the Pentagon to send National Guard troops into West Africa . By Thursday night , in an acknowledgement of the pressure to step up his response , Obama suggested he might need to appoint an “ Ebola czar . ”
“ We are taking this seriously , ” Obama said in the Oval Office . “ This is going to be something that is contained here . ”
But none of that has been enough for Republicans and even some Democrats , particularly those in close election fights , who say that he should take tougher steps ranging from firing the head of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to banning flights from some affected countries .
“ I ’ m greatly concerned , ” said Rep. Bruce Braley ( D-Iowa ) , who is locked in a tight Senate race , “ that the administration did not act fast enough responding in Texas . ”
After the first reported case in the U.S. two weeks ago , White House aides declined to put Obama front and center , concerned that such a move could stoke public panic . But as one Ebola case turned into three and the CDC began admitting mistakes in how it ’ s handled the problem , White House aides said they saw little choice but to thrust Obama into the middle of the response this week .
The president needed to make sure everybody knew he was on the case — and for good reason , given the political implications . But finding the right balance moving forward is the challenge .
Obama won ’ t stay locked in the White House until the Ebola crisis dies down , aides said . There ’ s still a lot going on in the world , they noted , and Obama must show he ’ s engaged on more issues than just Ebola . He is expected to make remarks Friday at the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and resume his campaign travels Sunday with a trip to Maryland and Chicago .
On Thursday , the president consulted with top congressional leaders , Democrat and Republican , on the role that lawmakers can take in tamping down the disease , such as providing more federal funds . Obama encouraged foreign leaders to contribute more aid to contain the spread of the disease in Africa . And he signed an executive order authorizing the Departments of Defense and Homeland Security to call up military reservists to augment U.S. forces on the ground in Liberia and elsewhere in West Africa .
“ I was … glad to see the president get off the campaign trail yesterday to finally focus on the crisis , ” Rep. Fred Upton ( R-Mich. ) said during a hearing Thursday on Capitol Hill . “ People are scared . We need all hands on deck . We need a strategy , and we need to protect the American people first and foremost . It ’ s not a drill . People ’ s lives are at stake , and the response so far has been unacceptable . ”
So far , the White House has rejected Republican calls for a ban , or at least a limitation , on travel from Liberia , Sierra Leone and Guinea . The White House has also declined to have the president deliver a prime-time address or fire CDC Director Tom Frieden . Until Thursday , it dismissed the idea of an Ebola czar .
